|Title=Knowing how to control the source of infection
|Description=Know how to seek surgical or radiointerventional advice to discuss the possible removal of an infectious source.
|Rubric=Management
|Contributors=
|Order=15}}
Surgical or radio-interventional control of the infectious source is essential in the following situations:

- Abdominal emergencies: peritoneal lavage (peritonitis), drainage of bile ducts (angiocholitis)

- Acute blocked pyelonephritis: urine diversion

- Endocarditis complicated by cardiogenic shock (valvular decay) or perivalvular abscess

- Arthritis with sepsis/septic shock or persistent bacteremia (joint lavage)

- Flattening or radiological drainage of an abscess

- Necrotizing fasciitis

properties.question: In the management of bacteremia/fungemia, which of the following situations may require surgical or radio-interventional control of the infectious source?
properties.option_a: Mild skin infection treated with topical antibiotics
properties.option_b: Abdominal emergencies such as peritonitis or drainage of bile ducts
properties.option_d: Muscle strain with no signs of infection
